simpledes: Post-tax private income corresponds to all sources of incomes, net of taxes, received by individuals and which can be individualized (this excludes social transfers in kind, collective consumption expenditure and government deficit).
technicaldes: Post-tax disposable income=Pre-tax income-Taxes on production (net)-Current taxes on income and wealth+Social assistance benefits in cash
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1982: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1983: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1989-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2004: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2005: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2006: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2007-2008: survey + tax data, 2009-2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

simpledes: Post-tax national income is the sum of primary incomes over all sectors (private and public), minus taxes.
technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1982: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1983: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1989-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2004: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2005: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2006: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2007-2008: survey + tax data, 2009-2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution

When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Tax units are households for 1914-1949, individuals aged 15+ for 1950-2008. Fractiles are defined by total income. Income excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2015 from: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2020/01/weodata/index.aspx/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF World Economic Outlook (04/2020, forecast)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 2016–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1913–2014: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

simpledes: Net domestic product is the total value of the goods and services produced in a country, minus the value of the fixed capital used up in production (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads).The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net domestic product]=[Gross domestic product]-[Consumption of fixed capital of national economy]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1913–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: Net domestic product is the total value of the goods and services produced in a country, minus the value of the fixed capital used up in production (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads).The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net domestic product]=[Gross domestic product]-[Consumption of fixed capital of national economy]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations.

simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from abroad]-[Property income paid abroad]+[Compensation of employees received from abroad]-[Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: extrapolated from last available year; 1995–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1982–1994: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1913–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

shortname: Property income paid from the rest of the world
simpledes: Property income paid abroad is the total value of payments made by the national economy accruing to property owners as remuneration for using their property.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Capital income paid to the rest of the world]=[Foreign direct investment income paid to the rest of the world]+[Portfolio and other income paid to the rest of the world]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1982: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1983: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1989-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2004: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2005: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2006: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2007-2008: survey + tax data, 2009-2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution. Before 1980, pretax income shares retropolated based on fiscal income: see source.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1995–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

technicaldes: [Gross secondary income/Gross saving of non-financial corporations]=[Gross primary income of non-financial corporations]-[Corporate tax]+[Social contributions to private employer social insurance]-[Social benefits from private employer social insurance]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Post-tax private income corresponds to all sources of incomes, net of taxes, received by individuals and which can be individualized (this excludes social transfers in kind, collective consumption expenditure and government deficit).
technicaldes: Post-tax disposable income=Pre-tax income-Taxes on production (net)-Current taxes on income and wealth+Social assistance benefits in cash
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1982: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1983: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1989-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2004: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2005: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2006: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2007-2008: survey + tax data, 2009-2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution

simpledes: Post-tax national income is the sum of primary incomes over all sectors (private and public), minus taxes.
technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Tax units are households for 1914-1949, individuals aged 15+ for 1950-2008. Fractiles are defined by total income. Income excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Tax units are households for 1914-1949, individuals aged 15+ for 1950-2008. Fractiles are defined by total income. Income excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.

simpledes: Current national income adjusted by CPI, divided by national income of the base year adjusted by CPI. It measures the changes in the purchasing power of national income.

method: We cumulate inflation rates from the following sources; 1913-1921: price index provided by the researchers (see source); 1922-1925: interpolation assuming a constant inflation rate; 1926-1944: price index provided by the researchers (see source); 1945: interpolation assuming a constant inflation rate; 1946-2016: price index provided by the researchers (see source); 2017-2018: GDP deflator from the World Bank; 2019: CPI from the World Bank.

simpledes: Index that reflects the availability of surveys and tax data enabling the measurement of income and wealth inequality.

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

method: The inequality transparency index is estimated by the World Inequality Lab based on the availability of income and wealth surveys and tax data in the country considered. See http://wid.world/transparency/ for more information .

shortname: Compensation of employees paid from the rest of the world
simpledes: Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world is the total value of income accruing to employees as remuneration for their work.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

shortname: Compensation of employees received from the rest of the world
simpledes: Compensation of employees received from abroad is the total value of wage and salary disbursements, and supplements to wages and salaries received by a country's residents, including wages and salaries received from the rest of the world.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.

These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: imputed value; 1995–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1992–1994: imputed value; 1976–1991: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1913–1975: imputed value. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Tax units are households for 1914-1949, individuals aged 15+ for 1950-2008. Fractiles are defined by total income. Income excludes capital gains.

shortname: Foreign income paid to the rest of the world
technicaldes: [Foreign income paid to the rest of the world]=[Labor and capital income paid to the rest of the world]-[Taxes on production paid to the rest of the world]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2015 from: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2020/01/weodata/index.aspx/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF World Economic Outlook (04/2020, forecast)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 2016–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1913–2014: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from abroad]-[Property income paid abroad]+[Compensation of employees received from abroad]-[Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: extrapolated from last available year; 1995–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1982–1994: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations.

method: From 1913 to 2015 we the use data provided by the WID researchers for total and adult population (see source). simpledes: Number of adults as tax units.
longtype: Number of units in a given group
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Adults correspond to individuals aged above 15.

simpledes: Post-tax private income corresponds to all sources of incomes, net of taxes, received by individuals and which can be individualized (this excludes social transfers in kind, collective consumption expenditure and government deficit).
technicaldes: Post-tax disposable income=Pre-tax income-Taxes on production (net)-Current taxes on income and wealth+Social assistance benefits in cash
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1982: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1983: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1989-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2004: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2005: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2006: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2007-2008: survey + tax data, 2009-2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution

simpledes: Post-tax national income is the sum of primary incomes over all sectors (private and public), minus taxes.
technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1982: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1983: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1989-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2004: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2005: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2006: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2007-2008: survey + tax data, 2009-2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Tax units are households for 1914-1949, individuals aged 15+ for 1950-2008. Fractiles are defined by total income. Income excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Tax units are households for 1914-1949, individuals aged 15+ for 1950-2008. Fractiles are defined by total income. Income excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1982: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1983: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1989-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2004: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2005: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2006: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2007-2008: survey + tax data, 2009-2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution. Before 1980, pretax income shares retropolated based on fiscal income: see source.

simpledes: Post-tax private income corresponds to all sources of incomes, net of taxes, received by individuals and which can be individualized (this excludes social transfers in kind, collective consumption expenditure and government deficit).
technicaldes: Post-tax disposable income=Pre-tax income-Taxes on production (net)-Current taxes on income and wealth+Social assistance benefits in cash
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Tax units are households for 1914-1949, individuals aged 15+ for 1950-2008. Fractiles are defined by total income. Income excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]

method: Tax units are households for 1914-1949, individuals aged 15+ for 1950-2008. Fractiles are defined by total income. Income excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Mavridis_Mosberger_Hungary_2017/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Mavridis, Dimitris and Mosberger, Palma (2017). Income inequality and incentives. The quasi-natural experiment of Hungary, 1914-2008[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

shortname: Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
simpledes: Pre-tax capital income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the individual owners of capital as a production factor, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]=Housing asset income+Equity asset income+Interest income+Pensions and social insurance income (capital share)-Interest payments
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]
simpledes: Pre-tax labor income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the individual owners of labor as a production factor, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]=Compensation of employees +Labor component of net mixed income +Pensions and social insurance income (labor share)
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
